reviewText: ...the television version of the "Living Legend" was much better.  I admit to buying this video strictly for that aspect of this haphazardly spliced-together film.  ("Fire In Space" episode by itself is okay too). Okay, to the plot (for the non-BSG familiar).  Lorne  Greene leads an aircraft-carrier sized spacecraft (the Battlestar  Galactica), with 200-some odd civilian craft in tow, in search of the  mythical planet Earth after their colonies were destroyed by a relentless  cybernetic race called the Cylons.  During a recon mission, two of his  patrol craft accidentally run into a patrol from another battlestar whose  legendary commander (Lloyd Bridges) they thought perished years ago. The  two commanders reunite, but quickly realize they have differences on how to  proceed.  Commander Adama (Greene) wants only fuel to get his fleet  underway while Commander Cain (Bridges) wants to put the smackdown on the  Cylons by any means necessary.  Interesting plot and outstanding special  effects (although some are blatantly rehashed AND stolen from the movie  "The Towering Inferno".  Good supporting cast too, including  Richard Hatch (Capt. Apollo), Dirk Benedict (Lt. Starbuck), Terry Carter  (Col. Tigh), Anne Lockhart (Lt. Sheba) and the late (but enjoyably oily)  John Colicos as the traitor Baltar.  Bottom line -- good escapist  entertainment.  I've loved the BSG series since I was a kid and the  "Living Legend" was the best of the lot.  I've heard rumors of  resurrecting the series as a movie, miniseries and even an IMAX movie.  (Whatever it takes, folks, just do it!)
Title: N/A

reviewText: I sold my VHS copy years ago when the PAL/Region 2 version came out from Universal Playback. The video transfer was great, but my only complaint is that it does not run the 108 minutes that the tape did. It doesn't make sense that they would edit it down more since a DVD-9 can store 120 minutes (actually 124)single layered. Now  I find myself looking for the VHS tape with the full length version. For those who have read the other comments, most are accurate except for the comments regarding the telefilm. This IS NOT the telefilm version. This was an actual theatrical release in 1979, about the same time that Battlestar Galactica (pilot film version 3) was released in the U.S. for the first time, this was released in UK and Canada as a theatrical release. It was never released in U.S. but is considered version 2, even though it was significantly altered. The telefilm that others refer to was the 2 hour version that was originally scheduled to run as one of 4 mini-series follow ups to the 3 hour movie. (Lost Planet of Gods, Gun On Ice Planet Zero, Living Legend, and War of the Gods)All were filmed with more scenes but later cut for fit in the one hour time slots so some footage had to go in each case. These were recut back into original form and presented as weekend syndication movies in some metro areas but also sold in UK on VHS in late 1990s. Universal then went back and asked Larson to repackage all the episodes into 2 hour telefilms. This was obviously done well after the series ended as scenes were hastily recreated from footage and/or actors were brought in to create scenes that would bridge the episodes together. Dialogue from certain characters did not match original cast (voice overs for Apollo were a bad mismatch)There was one odd episode out so for the final telefilm so they took Experiment in Terra and the last Galactica 1980 episode and reedited them together to create the extended version of the Experiment in Terra episode. Some of the telefilms were sold on VHS in UK. The only original telefilm version of War of The Gods was available in this set as a 2 hour film, the rest of them were the 2 part versions, including the 2 part version of Greetings From Earth, and the later produced telefilms.  To date, the only way to see the deleted/extended scenes of the series that were used in the telefilms, is to obtain the BSG complete Epic series set. Maybe some day they will release the true telefilms.
summary: More Complete than the UK DVD version

reviewText: This is a great film. Taken from some of the best episodes of the original galactica series. Let me get the bad points over with first. The editing at the end is crap! I could have done a better job. They cut out the cylons attacking the pegasus from part two of "Living Legend" and instead had the cylons attacking the galactica from "Fire in Space". I would have rather seen both. And they cut out the pegasus theme music and replaced with the usual galactica theme. Plus they had no explaination of Baltar's presence in the film considering that in the last film, Baltar was killed. But other than that, it was great. Apart from the end, the editing was pretty damn good throughout the rest of the film. The story was great, and it was filled with action. If you're a hard-core fan, or if you just have vage interest in the show and you don't want to buy the series, I highly recommend this film.

reviewText: This is the WORST Battlestar Galactica video out there! They took two of the best episodes of the series and mashing them together to try to make a movie out of it but instead succeeded in creating a confusing mishmosh of the episodes. Oh, and to a previous reviewer that noted that Adama wasn't injured in "The Living Legend", you are right. But he WAS injured in "Fire in Space" - guess Universal thought the scene was good enough to throw in just for some angst.DON'T BUY THIS VIDEO! IT'S AN INSULT TO "GALACTICA" FANS!
